pr_title: Stop onErrorDropped events from leaking into default Reactor Hook

timeline.message:
Stop onErrorDropped events from leaking into default Reactor Hook

There is a race condition between cancellation (via Reactor timeout) and completing the request in the Rntbd stack (via error/request timeout or successfully) which right now results in onErrorDropped events being raised to the default Reactor Hook. This results in ERROR level logging - functionally it is harmless (we do proper clean-up and functionally it is expected that the cancellation takes precedence and we ignore any subsequent success/transport exception). To avoid confusing customers I have injected a local hook now that will just log these errors with a DEBUG level - hopefully that will reduce the noise level for customers and stop causing confusion.

timeline.author: xinlian12

timeline.bodyText:
I think my biggest question is: if we can not offer this task back, what would happen for this task? we did not fail it or retry, so any possibility it will stuck somewhere?
PriorityBlockingQueue will never return false for the offer method, then I guess it should be fine here?
timeline.author: xinlian12

replies.bodyText: Yes - it is fine. the queue has unlimited capcity
replies.author: FabianMeiswinkel

replies.bodyText: I mean limited only by resource constraints - and since admission control is in place there is no issue.
replies.author: FabianMeiswinkel

replies.bodyText: got it, thanks for the explanation~
replies.author: xinlian12

timeline.message: Avoiding that we expire 1 ns too late :-)

timeline.author: kushagraThapar

timeline.bodyText: @FabianMeiswinkel Is this a feature of Reactor, if so is it documented somewhere? It's interesting.
timeline.author: allenhumphreys

replies.bodyText: Yes - it is a Reactor feature - but I found it via source code inspection. This is the commit in which it was added: reactor/reactor-core@b576f7f
replies.author: FabianMeiswinkel

replies.bodyText: The best features are always undocumented! My next question is why didn't you use Operators.KEY_ON_ERROR_DROPPED and/or provide a link to how it works? :-)
replies.author: allenhumphreys

replies.bodyText: Hooks.KEY_ON_ERROR_DROPPED is package internal. But fair point about comment. Will add it.
replies.author: FabianMeiswinkel

replies.bodyText: Ah! In the commit you posted they were public, but the actual source now is in Hooks and yes internal, I get it now! Thanks for adding the comment :-)
replies.author: allenhumphreys
